messages.text:
I’m thinking of making a JuliaAstro package that contains photometric filters and related functionality (eff wavelength, central wavelength, etc.). I’m thinking usage along the lines of
```filt = PhotometricFilters.V
wave(filt; units=true)
transmission(filt)
lam_eff = eff_wavelength(filt)
bp = BandPass(wl1, wl2)
plot(filt)
# etc...```
Goals wouldn’t be filter design but rather convenience functionality and quick calculations. Being able to do synethetic photometry e.g. is not the goal of this package. Data will likely be hard-coded into the source or downloaded via datadeps.

*Any thoughts on package names?*
Currently “PhotometricFilters.jl” is my top choice

messages.text:
I’ve currently updated the Transits.jl readme with some TODOs and plans. It’d be awesome to see some contributions on this. In addition, anybody with expertise in the field is more than welcome to write up some documentation that is mostly exposition rather than API reference if you don’t want to dig into the code as much.

<https://github.com/JuliaAstro/Transits.jl>

messages.text: Hello everyone, I started experimenting with the Julia language. For fun, I translated some X-ray pulsar search functionality from Python to Julia. The repo is here: <https://github.com/matteobachetti/psrsearch.jl>. Is there interest for this kind of code in JuliaAstro?

messages.text: Transits.jl already works with Turing! ForwardDiff gradients are a few multiples slower than the analytical gradients, so there is definitely performance to be unlocked, but I got a really simple model working using turing and NUTS :slightly_smiling_face: it only took me ~2 minutes to get 3000 samples with 90% acceptance rate

elements.text: Transits.jl already works with Turing! ForwardDiff gradients are a few multiples slower than the analytical gradients, so there is definitely performance to be unlocked, but I got a really simple model working using turing and NUTS
it only took me ~2 minutes to get 3000 samples with 90% acceptance rate

messages.text: Hello everyone! I am Nikhil. I am interested in working on the vectorized implementation of NOVAS library in Julia. After a bit of searching, I found the C source code on <http://www.ascl.net/1202.003>. However, I could not find anything on GitHub so I'm not sure where to upload the code. Any help would be appreciated! I am currently going through the code base and plan to start implementing the custom data structures soon.

messages.text: astro Julia paper: <https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.09252> a Signal to Noise Analysis Pipeline to study exoplanets

attachments.title: Improved Contrast in Images of Exoplanets using Direct SNR Optimization
attachments.text: Direct imaging of exoplanets is usually limited by quasi-static speckles. These uncorrected aberrations in a star's point spread function (PSF) obscure faint companions and limit the sensitivity...
attachments.fallback: arXiv.org: Improved Contrast in Images of Exoplanets using Direct SNR Optimization

messages.text: Hi everyone! I’m Chia-Yu at Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics (MPE) working on hydrodynamical simulations and ISM chemistry (any simulators here?). I recently released a chemistry code: <https://github.com/huchiayu/AstroChemistry.jl> which performs PDR calculations with user-defined chemistry networks (using the UMIST database). It can be used in simple one-zone models as well as post-processing hydro simulations in 3D. Questions and feedback are most welcome :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi everyone! I’m Chia-Yu at Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics (MPE) working on hydrodynamical simulations and ISM chemistry (any simulators here?). I recently released a chemistry code:

messages.text:
Hi everyone :) I’m a physics student in Mexico and I’m interested in participating in GSoC 2021, this is my first time participating. I’m particularly interested in the NOVAS project, is anyone already working on it?

I saw in the description of the project that the project is of medium difficulty. I consider myself a beginner in the Julia language, however, I consider I could dedicate a fair amount of time to study the language in April since I’m only writing my thesis at the moment, would you consider that’s enough time to make a good work for GSoC?

I see that there exists a package that’s called einsteinpy regarding general relativity. Since that’s a topic I like, I was wondering if there would be someone interested in being a mentor of a project related to it? I can think of maybe making a Julia version of a ray tracer, like the one proposed in this paper:
<http://courses.csail.mit.edu/18.337/2015/projects/RyanMcKinnon/report.pdf>

messages.text: Hi <@U01S831AG1H>, there are several people interested in working on NOVAS. However, no decisions have been made as yet. I’d recommend reviewing the GSOC guidelines for applicants and brushing up on your Julia knowledge.

, there are several people interested in working on NOVAS. However, no decisions have been made as yet. I’d recommend reviewing the GSOC guidelines for applicants and brushing up on your Julia knowledge.

messages.text: I wanted to share this new Kepler solver <https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15829> but I see <@U8442MDS6> is already on it :smile: i feel like a Julia implementation would be pretty fast (especially using `sincos`), but I believe this method is also way more expensive than <https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00691917> (and the fact that they don't mention Markley's solver makes me think they don't know it)

attachments.title: Kepler Equation solver
attachments.text: Kepler's Equation is solved over the entire range of elliptic motion by a fifth-order refinement of the solution of a cubic equation. This method is not iterative, and requires only four transcendental function evaluations: a square root, a cube root, and two trigonometric functions. The maximum relative error of the algorithm is less than one part in 1018, exceeding the capability of double-precision computer arithmetic. Roundoff errors in double-precision implementation of the algorithm are addressed, and procedures to avoid them are developed.
attachments.fallback: Celestial Mechanics and Dynamical Astronomy: Kepler Equation solver
